title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: genome-wide association studies (GWAS) continue expand scope diversity, precise quantification study’s ancestral makeup become increasingly important. afmix() function GAUSS package, provides users robust method accurately estimating ancestry proportions within multi-ethnic GWAS, utilizing solely summary statistics data. vignette offers step--step guide effectively employ afmix() function.

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
code: library(gauss) library(dplyr) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: afmix() function requires four specific arguments: input_file: File name allele frequency data reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data Upon execution, afmix() function return data.frame comprising three columns: sup.pop: super population name pop: population name wgt: population proportion

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: allele frequency data file formatted space-delimited text file, containing six specific columns: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), af1 (reference allele frequency). vignette, using allele frequency data Chromosome 22 Psychiatric Genomic Consortium’s Phase 2 Schizophrenia (PGC SCZ2) GWAS. , specify path allele frequency data file.
code: # Path to the input file input_file <- "../data/PGC2_Chr22_ilmn1M_AF1.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and af1) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2       af1 #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G 0.1159800 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C 0.1240050 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G 0.2660650 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G 0.6319500 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C 0.9570250 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G 0.0667805

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: Next, assign paths reference panel data files. example, use 33KG reference panel.
code: # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file <-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: necessary arguments data files place, ready run afmix() function compute ancestry proportion PGC SCZ2 GWAS.
code: wgt.df <- afmix(input_file=input_file,                 reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                 reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                 reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file)

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: , display estimated ancestry proportions HTML table.
code: wgt.df %>% kable("html")

what: Summarizing Ancestry Proportions by Super Population
title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: , calculate total proportion super population present results table.
code: wgt.df %>%   group_by(sup.pop) %>%   summarise(wgt=sum(wgt), .groups="drop") %>%   kable("html")

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: Lee et al. DISTMIX: direct imputation summary statistics unmeasured SNPs mixed ethnicity cohorts. Bioinformatics. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btv348

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Linkage disequilibrium (LD) quantifies degree non-random association alleles different loci within population. estimation LD multi-ethnic cohorts, however, can challenging due underlying population structure. computeLD() function GAUSS package addresses challenge offering efficient accurate method estimate LD, factoring mixed ancestries present cohort. vignette provide step--step guide using computeLD() estimating LD SNPs within multi-ethnic Schizophrenia GWAS cohort.

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(reshape2) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: computeLD() function GAUSS package designed estimate Linkage Disequilibrium (LD) leveraging observed estimated ancestry proportions target cohort. calculates LD specific genomic regions weighted sum LD values across various ancestries. LD values ancestry estimated reference panel. example, utilize 33KG reference panel estimations. function requires following arguments: chr: Chromosome number. start_bp: Starting base pair position estimation window. end_bp: Ending base pair position estimation window. pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population IDs wights input_file: File name association Z-score data reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data af1_cutff: Cutoff reference allele (a1) frequency computeLD() function returns list two elements: snplist: data frame containing information SNPs used LD estimation. cormat: matrix LD estimates pair SNPs.

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: ancestry proportion data pop_wgt_df include two columns following names: pop (population abbreviation) wgt (weight proportion). information estimated using afmix() function described . , load ancestry proportion data generated vignette afmix() function:
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: association Z-score data file space-delimited text file including six columns following names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score). assign path association Z-score data file :
code: # Define the path to the input file input_file <- "../data/PGC2_3Mb.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input_data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input_data) #>          rsid chr        bp a1 a2         z #> 1:  rs1004467  10 104594507  A  G  6.686674 #> 2:  rs1008013  10 103548866  A  T -1.769923 #> 3: rs10128116  10 103717613  A  G -1.883298 #> 4:  rs1015037  10 105547517  T  G -1.917614 #> 5: rs10159775  10 103184297  A  G  1.304979 #> 6: rs10159838  10 105473937  A  G  2.582526

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Next, assign paths reference panel data files:
code: # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file <-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: necessary arguments data prepared, can now estimate Linkage Disequilibrium specific genomic region using computeLD() function. example, focus 1Mb genomic region located Chromosome 10: 104-105 Mb.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- computeLD(chr=10,                   start_bp = 104000001,                   end_bp = 105000000,                  pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,                  input_file = input_file,                   reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                  reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                   reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,                  af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Let’s display first entries results: Finally, generate heatmap visually represent LD estimates:
code: head(res$snplist) %>% kable("html") head(res$cormat[1:3,1:3]) #>            [,1]      [,2]       [,3] #> [1,]  1.0000000 0.3862755 -0.2043549 #> [2,]  0.3862755 1.0000000  0.3080546 #> [3,] -0.2043549 0.3080546  1.0000000 cormat <- res$cormat diag(cormat) <- NA cormelt <- melt(cormat, na.rm = TRUE)  p1 <- ggplot(data = cormelt, aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = value)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_gradient2(low = "blue", high = "red",                         mid = "white",                         midpoint = 0, limit = c(-1,1),                         space = "Lab") +   scale_y_reverse() +   theme_minimal() +    theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(),         axis.text.y = element_blank(),         axis.ticks = element_blank(),         axis.title.x = element_blank(),         axis.title.y = element_blank(),         panel.grid.major = element_blank(),         panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),         legend.position = "none") +   coord_fixed()  p1 #ggsave(file="docs/figure/computeLD_example.pdf", p1)

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Lee et al. DISTMIX: direct imputation summary statistics unmeasured SNPs mixed ethnicity cohorts. Bioinformatics. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btv348

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: growing availability larger, ethnically diverse reference panels increased need efficient re-imputation genotype data updated GWAS. GAUSS package streamlines tasks two specialized functions—dist() distmix()—imputing association Z-scores unmeasured SNPs. vignette guide practical application dist() distmix() imputing association Z-scores ethnically homogeneous multi-ethnic cohorts.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: dist() distmix() functions require two core input datasets: Association Z-score Data Reference Panel Data

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: data form space-delimited text file including six columns following names: rsid: SNP ID chr: Chromosome number bp: Base pair position a1: Reference allele a2: Alternative allele z: Association Z-score example, use Psychiatric Genomic Consortium’s Phase 2 Schizophrenia (PGC SCZ2) GWAS dataset.
code: # Path to the input file input_file <- "../data/PGC2_3Mb.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>          rsid chr        bp a1 a2         z #> 1:  rs1004467  10 104594507  A  G  6.686674 #> 2:  rs1008013  10 103548866  A  T -1.769923 #> 3: rs10128116  10 103717613  A  G -1.883298 #> 4:  rs1015037  10 105547517  T  G -1.917614 #> 5: rs10159775  10 103184297  A  G  1.304979 #> 6: rs10159838  10 105473937  A  G  2.582526

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: use 33KG reference panel. Replace file paths actual reference panel files.
code: reference_index_file <-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: dist() function specifically designed ethnically homogeneous cohorts. allows direct imputation association Z-scores unmeasured SNPs, making easier update enhance GWAS analyses.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: dist() function accepts following arguments: chr: Chromosome number. start_bp: Starting base pair position estimation window. end_bp: Ending base pair position estimation window. wing_size: Size area flanking left right estimation window study_pop: Study population group input_file: File name association Z-score data reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data af1_cutoff: Cutoff reference allele (a1) frequency

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: dist() function returns data frame following columns: rsid: SNP ID. chr: Chromosome number. bp: Base pair position. a1: Reference allele. a2: Alternative allele. af1ref: Reference allele frequency. z: Association Z-score. pval: Association P-value. info: Imputation information, ranging 0 1. type: Type variant. value 0 indicates imputed variant, 1 denotes measured variant.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: example, execute dist() function impute association Z-scores missing SNPs 1Mb genomic region (Chromosome 10: 104 - 105 Mb) PGC SCZ2 study. sake example, let’s assume study cohort consists participants European descent, represented “EUR.” Therefore, ’ll set study_pop = "EUR" utilize genotype data European subjects 33KG reference panel.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- dist(chr=10,              start_bp = 104000001,              end_bp = 105000000,              wing_size = 500000,              study_pop = "EUR",             input_file = input_file,              reference_index_file = reference_index_file,             reference_data_file = reference_data_file,              reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,             af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: distmix() function designed multi-ethnic cohorts, extending capabilities dist() accommodate complexities introduced ethnic diversity data.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: distmix() function takes set arguments largely identical dist(). However, instead study_pop argument, distmix() incorporates pop_wgt_df: pop_wgt_df: R data frame specifies population IDs respective ancestry proportions.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: output distmix() also largely identical dist(), one exception: column af1mix replaces af1ref. af1mix: estimated reference allele frequency variant study cohort. calculated weighted sum reference allele frequencies across different populations reference panel.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: using distmix(), need prepare ancestry proportion data. data structured data frame containing two columns: pop: Population abbreviation wgt: Weight proportion population study cohort. can estimate proportions using afmix() function. step--step guide process, refer afmix() vignette. , load pre-generated ancestry proportion data: Now, let’s proceed use distmix() imputing association Z-scores missing SNPs 1Mb genomic region Chromosome 10, ranging 104 105 Mb.
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018 af1_cutoff = 0.001  res.mix <- distmix(chr=10,              start_bp = 104000001,              end_bp = 105000000,              wing_size = 500000,              pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,             input_file = input_file,              reference_index_file = reference_index_file,             reference_data_file = reference_data_file,              reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,             af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: head(res.mix) %>% kable("html")

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: res.mix.info <- res.mix %>% filter(info>0.6) res.mix.info$type <- factor(res.mix.info$type,                              levels=c(0, 1),                             labels=c("Imputed","Measured")) gwas.sig <- 5*10^-8    ggplot(res.mix.info, aes(x = bp, y = -log10(pval),                           color = info, shape=type)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +   geom_hline(aes(yintercept = -log10(gwas.sig)),               linetype = "dashed",               color = "black",               size = 1.5) +   scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red") +   labs(x = "Base Pair Position",        y = "-Log10(p-value)",        color = "Info",        shape = "Type") +   theme_minimal() #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: Lee et al. DIST: direct imputation summary statistics unmeasured SNPs. Bioinformatics . 2013 Nov 15;29(22):2925-7. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btt500. Lee et al. DISTMIX: direct imputation summary statistics unmeasured SNPs mixed ethnicity cohorts. Bioinformatics. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btv348

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: vignette provides detailed guide use distmix() function impute association Z-scores unmeasured SNPs multi-ethnic cohorts. ’ll cover essential arguments needed showcase practical example.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: distmix() function requires following arguments: chr: Chromosome number. start_bp: Starting base pair position prediction window. end_bp: Ending base pair position prediction window. wing_size: Size area flanking left right prediction window. pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population IDs wights input_file: File name association Z-score data reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data af1_cutff: Cutoff reference allele (a1) frequency

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: ancestry proportion data pop_wgt_df include two columns following names: pop (population abbreviation) wgt (weight proportion). infomormation estimated using afmix() function described . information already available, load data. Let’s load ancestry proportion data generated vignette afmix() function:
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: association Z-score data file space-delimited text file including six columns following names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score). , assign path association Z-score data file:
code: # Define the path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input_data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input_data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: Next, assign paths reference panel data files:
code: # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: now execute distmix() function necessary arguments store results:
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- distmix(chr=22, start_bp = 26000001, end_bp = 26100000, wing_size = 100000,               pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,               input_file = input_file,                reference_index_file = reference_index_file,               reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,               af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: Let’s display results neat table:
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: , create Manhattan Plot visually represent results:
code: res.info <- res %>% filter(info>0.6) gwas.sig <- 5*10^-8    ggplot(res.info, aes(x = bp, y = -log10(pval), color = info)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +   geom_hline(aes(yintercept = -log10(gwas.sig)),               linetype = "dashed",               color = "red",               linewidth = 1.0) +   scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red") +   labs(title = "Manhattan Plot",        x = "Base Pair Position",        y = "-Log10(p-value)",        color = "Info") +   theme_minimal()

title: Winner's curse adjustment
text: many genetic association studies involve extensive multiple testing, ’s often observed association signals statistical significance threshold greater impact trait variation statistically significant. Accurately quantifying sub-threshold effects crucial challenging due biases known “Winner’s Curse.” previous work, developed FIQT (FDR Inverse Quantile Transformation), straightforward technique correct biases. Initially, FIQT uses False Discovery Rate (FDR) correct p-values SNP associations multiple testing. derives Z-score noncentrality estimates based Gaussian quantiles correspond adjusted p-values, maintaining correct sign. FIQT approach conveniently incorporated GAUSS package fiqt() function. simply entering Z-score vector along minimum non-zero p-value generated qnorm() function (default value 10^-320), function produce Z-score vector adjusted account winner’s curse biases.

title: Winner's curse adjustment
code: library(gauss) #>  #> Attaching package: 'gauss' #> The following object is masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     dist library(tidyverse) #> ── Attaching packages #> ─────────────────────────────────────── #> tidyverse 1.3.2 ── #> ✔ ggplot2 3.4.1     ✔ purrr   0.3.4 #> ✔ tibble  3.1.8     ✔ dplyr   1.0.9 #> ✔ tidyr   1.2.0     ✔ stringr 1.4.0 #> ✔ readr   2.1.2     ✔ forcats 0.5.2 #> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() library(data.table) #>  #> Attaching package: 'data.table' #>  #> The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr': #>  #>     between, first, last #>  #> The following object is masked from 'package:purrr': #>  #>     transpose library(kableExtra) #>  #> Attaching package: 'kableExtra' #>  #> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': #>  #>     group_rows

title: Winner's curse adjustment
text: example, ’ll correct “Winner’s Curse” bias using fiqt() function applied summary statistics Psychiatric Genomics Consortium Schizophrenia Phase 3 study. demonstration purposes, limited analysis SNPs Illumina 1M Chip .

title: Winner's curse adjustment
code: pgc3$z.wca <- fiqt(pgc3$z)

title: Winner's curse adjustment
code: head(pgc3) %>% kable("html")

what: Original Z-scores vs FIQT Z-score noncentrality estimates
title: Winner's curse adjustment
code: ggplot() +   geom_point(aes(x=z, y=z.wca), data=pgc3) +   geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1, color="red") +   labs(x="Original Z-score",       y="Estimated Z-score noncentrality",       caption="Data: PGC SCZ3 GWAS") +   theme_classic()

title: Winner's curse adjustment
text: Bigdeli et al. simple yet accurate correction winner’s curse can predict signals discovered much larger genome scans. Bioinformatics. 2016 Sep 1;32(17):2598-603. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btw303.

code: sudo port selfupdate sudo port install gsl

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) serve powerful framework identifying functional relationships genetic variations complex traits. integrating results Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) rich functional annotations, TWAS provides comprehensive view genetic architecture traits diseases. GAUSS offers robust suite tools streamline enhance TWAS analyses. Two specialized functions, jepeg() jepegmix(), offer tailored solutions homogeneous multi-ethnic cohorts, respectively. vignette aims comprehensive guide, walking hands-application jepeg() jepegmix() conducting TWAS.

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: jepeg() jepegmix() functions necessitate three core input datasets: Association Z-score Data SNP Annotation Data Reference Panel Data

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: data form space-delimited text file including six columns following names: rsid: SNP ID chr: Chromosome number bp: Base pair position a1: Reference allele a2: Alternative allele z: Association Z-score example, use Psychiatric Genomic Consortium’s Phase 2 Schizophrenia (PGC SCZ2) GWAS dataset.
code: # Path to the input file input_file <- "../data/PGC2_Chr22_ilmn1M_Z.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: SNP Annotation Data placed accessible directory, shown :
code: # Paths to the annotation file (replace these with your actual paths) annotation_file <- "../data/JEPEG_SNP_Annotation.v1.0.txt"

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: using 33KG reference panel. Make sure replace file paths actual reference panel files.
code: reference_index_file <-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"../ref/Human/33KG/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: jepeg() function enables researchers perform TWAS assessing joint effect expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) functional variants within specific gene phenotype. requires SNP annotation file provides linkage SNPs corresponding gene-level functional characteristics. integrating data, jepeg() formulates gene-level test statistics, aiming pinpoint genes whose expression levels might modulated genetic variations.”

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: jepeg() function requires following arguments: study_pop: Study population group input_file: File name association Z-score data annotation: File name SNP annotation data set reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data af1_cutoff: Cutoff reference allele (a1) frequency

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: jepeg() function returns data frame following columns: geneid: Gene name. chisq: Chi-square test statistic value df: Degrees freedom jepeg_pval: JEPEG p-value num_snp: Number functional SNPs associated gene top_categ: Top functional category top_categ_pval: Top category p-value top_snp: Top functional SNP ID top_snp_pval: Top functional SNP p-value

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: example, use jepeg() function perform TWAS analysis utilizing summary statistics PGC SCZ2 GWAS dataset. Assuming study cohort consists participants British descent, specify study_pop = "GBR". ensure function employs genotype data individuals Britain, specifically England Scotland, sourced 33KG reference panel.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- jepeg(study_pop = "GBR",              input_file=input_file,              annotation_file=annotation_file,              reference_index_file = reference_index_file,              reference_data_file = reference_data_file,              reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file)  res <- res[order(res$jepeg_pval),]

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: studies involve diverse ethnic backgrounds, jepegmix() extends utility jepeg() accommodate complexities introduced ethnic heterogeneity.

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: jepegmix() function accepts arguments jepeg(). However, replaces study_pop argument pop_wgt_df: pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population names corresponding ancestry proportions.

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: output jepegmix() identical jepeg().

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: using jepegmix(), need prepare ancestry proportion data. data structured data frame containing two columns: pop: Population abbreviation wgt: Corresponding proportion population estimate ancestry proportions, afmix() function can employed. step--step guide process, refer afmix() vignette. , load pre-generated ancestry proportion data: Now, let’s proceed use jepegmix() conduct TWAS. , assume study cohort includes participants diverse ethnic backgrounds.
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018 af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- jepegmix(pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,                 input_file=input_file,                 annotation_file=annotation_file,                 reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                 reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                 reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,                 af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)  res <- res[order(res$jepeg_pval),]

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Transcriptome wide association study with GAUSS
text: Lee et al. JEPEG: summary statistics based tool gene-level joint testing functional variants. Bioinformatics, Volume 31, Issue 8, April 2015, Pages 1176–1182, https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btu816 Lee et al. JEPEGMIX: gene-level joint analysis functional SNPs cosmopolitan cohorts. Bioinformatics. 2016 Jan 15; 32(2): 295–297. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btv567

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
text: jepegmix() function requires following arguments: pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population IDs wights input_file: file name GWAS summary statistics data containing rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2 z annotation: file name SNP annotation data set reference_index_file: file name reference panel index data reference_data_file: file name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: file name reference panel population description data af1_cutoff: cutoff reference allele, a1, frequency GWAS summary statistics data file include six columns following column names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score).

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
text: ancestry proportion data pop_wgt_df include two columns following names: pop (population abbreviation) wgt (weight proportion). information estimated using afmix() function described . information already available, load data. Let’s load ancestry proportion data generated vignette afmix() function: Firstly, assign path association Z-score data file. Next, assign paths reference data files variables
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018 # Path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244 # Paths to the annotation file (replace these with your actual paths) annotation_file <- "/path/to/JEPEG_SNP_Annotation.v1.0.txt" # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
text: Lastly, execute jepegmix() function necessary arguments display results neat table.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- jepegmix(pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,                 input_file=input_file,                 annotation_file=annotation_file,                 reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                 reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                 reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,                 af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)  res <- res[order(res$jepegmix_pval),]

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lee D (2023). gauss: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics. R package version 1.0, https://github.com/statsleelab/gauss.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gauss: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics},   author = {Donghyung Lee},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0},   url = {https://github.com/statsleelab/gauss}, }

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: GAUSS (Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics) versatile R package designed analysis multi-ethnic GWAS summary statistics. leverages large multi-ethnic reference panel consisting 32,953 genomes (33KG Panel), including 20,281 Europeans, 10,800 East Asians, 522 South Asians, 817 Africans, 533 Native Americans. GAUSS package offers robust set tools enable researchers : ) accurately estimate ancestry proportions within multi-ethnic GWAS (afmix() zimx()), ii) calculate ancestry-informed linkage disequilibrium (LD) metrics (computeLD()), iii) impute Z-scores genetic variants originally measured (dist() distmix()), iv) conduct -depth transcriptome-wide association studies (jepeg() jepegmix()), v) apply corrections ‘Winner’s Curse’ biases (fiqt()).

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: Lee Bacanu. GAUSS: comprehensive R package computation linkage disequlibrium variants, Gaussian imputation TWAS analysis cosmopolitan cohorts.

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: Donghyung Lee leed13@miamioh.edu

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: installing GAUSS, essential set GNU Scientific Library (GSL), dependency GAUSS package. Detailed installation instructions GSL available .

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: can install development version gauss GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("statsleelab/gauss")

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: GAUSS functions utilize five core input datasets: ) Association Z-score Data (highlighted blue), consisting six columns variables: SNP ID (rsid), chromosome number (chr), base pair position (bp), reference allele (a1), alternative allele (a2), Z-score (z); ii) Allele Frequency Data (colored red), encapsulating rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, reference allele frequency (af1); iii) Ethnic Mixing Proportion Data (colored green), comprising population name abbreviations corresponding mixing proportions; iv) SNP Annotation Data (colored orange), offering functional annotation information SNPs; v) Reference Panel Data (colored yellow), e.g., 33KG Panel offering genotype information significant pool 32,953 individuals 29 diverse ethnic groups. Initially, users determine whether input summary statistics data originate mixed ethnicity cohorts. (suggesting data comes homogeneous cohort), users can use variety analysis functions specific homogeneous cohorts, including computeLD() LD estimation, dist() imputing Z-scores missing SNPs, jepeg() conducting trascriptome-wide associaton study (TWAS). functions primarily require Association Z-score Data Reference Panel Data. Conversely, data derive mixed ethnicity cohorts ethnic mixing proportions known, GAUSS provides range tools multi-ethnic cohort analysis. encompass computeLD() LD estimation, distmix() Z-score imputation, jepegmix() TWAS. tools require Association Z-score Data, Reference Panel Data, Mixing Proportion Data. ethnic mixing proportions known, estimated using either afmix() function (Allele Frequency Data available) zmix() function (). Upon determining ethnic mixing proportions, users can apply genome analysis functions designed multi-ethnic cohorts. Small colored squares arrows pointing GAUSS functions denote required input data sets function. instance, arrow pointing afmix() function marked two colored squares (red yellow), indicating function utilizes Allele Frequency Data Reference Panel Data inputs. detailed examples demonstrate functionality, please visit GAUSS vignettes
